text: these modern mummies preserved skinless
human cadavers are the latest fad in the
exhibition world more than 22 million
people have lined up in cities like New
York Houston Tokyo and London to see
real human bodies on display but where
do these bodies come from in China a
bizarre new industry has emerged body
factories that preserve and produce
human corpses for museum exhibitions I'm
going to take you to one of the biggest
factories
this is David Barbosa reporting from
Dalian China for the New York Times
[Music]
Gunther von Hagens a controversial
German medical doctor is the creator of
Body Worlds
the first wildly successful anatomy
exhibition that has spawned several
imitators
he has been dubbed dr. death in dr.
Frankenstein by those who for more than
a decade have questioned the source of
his cadavers and how he displays them
but a few weeks ago he agreed to a
lengthy interview and a tour of what he
calls his Chinese manufacturing facility
located in a series of unmarked
buildings dr. van Hagen says he wants to
clear up the confusion about his work
and that of his competitors I should be
meeting inventor developer figure
impersonation when it comes to
technology when it comes to quality
tomorrow piece of anatomy when it comes
to ethical standards sporting a black
fedora which he almost never takes off
dr. von Hagens took me in another
journalist through a campus filled with
underground bunkers dissection rooms and
a warehouse crowded with steel
containers holding human and animal
remains when we arrived in the storage
area he called on his workers to open
everything
he wanted to show off his prized
specimens human and animal cadavers that
he planned to preserve through a process
he invented and patented called
plastination in one underground bunker
his staff pulled a bear out of a
container that he said had just come
from a German Zoo and when they lifted
the lid on another there were several
human bodies floating in formaldehyde
many shows featuring preserved human
cadavers have been accused of using
unclaimed Chinese bodies but dr. von
Hagens insisted all his exhibition
bodies come from donors mostly from
Europe once inside his factory a team of
workers dissect the corpses or saws them
into slices while frozen later body
fluids are removed and eventually
replaced with a soft polymer or plastic
creating a human plastinated specimen
the final stage is the positioning room
we're about 50 medical school graduates
clean the bodies impose them in lifelike
positions for the traveling exhibitions
this is what it is like to walk into a
room of assembly line workers and see
them dissecting skinless corpses
imposing them in playful positions like
holding a guitar dr. von Hagens told us
this was all about education in making
the study of anatomy fun but this
factory is also big business
besides the vast millions made on
exhibitions part of this facility is
producing books DVDs toys and Anatomy
games for schools the business is so big
that several other Chinese entrepreneurs
are jumping in including some of dr. von
Hagens former employees Kobe for
everybody's coffee coming dr. von Hagens
calls their work shoddy in hints that
some of them may be obtaining bodies
illegally the Chinese authorities are
now investigating whether these
factories are fostering an illegal trade
in human corpses in the past week the
Chinese authorities have put out new
regulations outlawing the buying or
selling of human bodies or body parts
they've also introduced new restrictions
on the import and export of human bodies
still several Chinese workers here said
they come because it's difficult to find
work after medical school in dr. von
Hagens he says he came to China because
it's the world's factory floor and it's
rich in skilled workers making toys
electronics and now human bodies this is
David Barbosa reporting for The New York
Times
[Music]
